name: LECTURE

values.comments:
MEAM 347 is a junior level laboratory course that teaches the principles of
design and measurement systems including basic electromechanical systems. It follows
MEAM 302 and MEAM 321 including experiments in fluid mechanics, and vibration in
the design of mechanical systems.
Generally, students found the course to be time-consuming and poorly organized.
Many complained that the unclear expectations and the disorganized lecture material.
Some indicated “lectures crammed way too much information into way too little time”
and that there was “a disconnection” between the corresponding classes and the labs.
However, students still felt that this course was “interesting and informative” in that it
made them apply theoretical knowledge, though it was “too open-ended with little
guidance.”
Professor Yim was described as a great instructor who covered many topics that
were “very useful to know.” Nevertheless, students generally found Professor Yim and
his TAs did not give clear announcements regarding the deadlines of the assignments.
Also, students hoped that Professor Yim could give more detailed help and feedbacks
with their labs.
The workload for this course was widely regarded as heavy. More than one
student reported that they needed to spend more than 20 hours a week doing the
assignments. Trying to adjust to the changing deadlines is one common problem
indicated by the students. Given the large amounts of time required, this course is only
recommended for majors. The prerequisite is junior standing in engineering.

This is a junior level laboratory course. The course teaches the principles of
design and measurement systems including basic electromechanical systems. It follows
MEAM 302 and MEAM 321 including experiments in fluid mechanics, and vibration in
the design of mechanical systems.
Some students thought that the class was “interesting and informative,” offering a
chance to “apply what [they have] learned in theoretical classes.” However, almost
everyone agreed that the course was “very disorganized,” which was not “very conducive
to learning the concepts.” One student commented on the “overall shoddiness” of the
mechanical design lab used for the class.
Students were critical of the professors’ approach to the course, which involved
having the class “[guess] what the professor wants instead of [focusing] on the material
itself.” Although several students wrote that this may have been intentional to encourage
“independent problem [solving],” they felt that the professors did not provide an
instruction at all for the labs. One student surmised that this and other administrative
problems arose because “neither [professor] took full ownership of the class.”
This course was described as “stressful, unfulfilling, and not enjoyable.” At one
point, there were “three ongoing lab assignments” that overlapped, making it difficult to
meet with team members. Conversely, there was “nothing to do” on some weeks.
Deadlines and assignment criteria were often changed at the last minute, encouraging
students to leave things “until the last minute.” There were also daily quizzes, further
adding to the extreme difficulty of the class.
